COOKIES - LOCAL STORAGE - SESSION STORAGE - and some Tailwind

TAILWIND

*Install Tailwind: npm install tailwindcss
Paste these into your css file:
@tailwind base;

@tailwind components;

@tailwind utilities;

*Use CDN(limited use): <link href="https://unpkg.com/tailwindcss@^1.0/dist/tailwind.min.css" rel="stylesheet">

*Customize defaults by creating a config file: npx tailwindcss init

COOKIES

Capacity: 4kb (much less capacity)
Browsers: HTML4/HTML5 (compatible with much older browsers)
Accessible From: Any window
Expires: Manually set
Storage Location: Browser and Server
Sent with Requests: Yes (sent along with every request that occurs)

LOCAL STORAGE

Capacity: 10mb (largest capacity)
Browsers: HTML5
Accessible From: Any window
Expires: Never (handle clear in logic or user clears from browser)
Storage Location: Browser only
Sent with Requests: No

SESSION STORAGE

Capacity: 5mb
Browsers: HTML5
Accessible From: Same tab only
Expires: On tab close
Storage Location: Browser only
Sent with Requests: No

USE CASES between them

Cookies are best for any data that needs to be accessed by both the server and the local machine as well as for anything that you want to set an expiration date on. Cookies are often used for things such as authentication information that need to be regularly sent back and forth.

Local Storage and Session Storage will be appropriate for most use cases as long as modern browser compatibility is fine.

IMPLEMENTATION

LOCAL STORAGE: (key value pairs)
localStorage.setItem('name', 'Juanito')
const name = localStorage.getItem('name')
console.log(name) //'Juanito'
localStorage.removeItem('name') //removes key/value
localStorage.clear() //removes everything

SESSION STORAGE: (similar to local storage)
sessionStorage.setItem('date', '8/20/20')
const date = sessionStorage.getItem('date')
console.log(date) //'8/20/20'
sessionStorage.removeItem('date') //removes key/value
sessionStorage.clear() //removes everything

COOKIES: (similar to local storage)
// this cookie isn't defined with an expiration and will default to expire with the session
document.cookie = 'hello=true'

// this cookie has an expiration
document.cookie = 'doSomethingOnlyOnce=true; expires=Fri, 31 Dec 9999 23:59:59 GMT'

// this cookie also has a path parameter defined at the root; this parameter associates the cookie for use with a specified path document.cookie = 'person=jorge; expires=Fri, 31 Dec 9999 23:59:59 GMT; path=/'

// logging the cookie will log all of your cookies as one long string; you would need to use a parser to manage them individually
console.log(document.cookie)

// to delete a cookie...
// reference the same key but omit the value, assign a past date, assign the same path if one was used
document.cookie = 'person=; expires=Fri, 31 Dec 1980 00:00:00 GMT; path=/'
